What is the rationale for this step: Establishes institutional trust by showing the school’s roots and mission-driven focus.

Founding year (2005) and original vision of online accessibility.

Expansion into middle-school division and adult diploma pathway.
Thousands of graduates.

Non-public school under Minnesota Statute 302A.

Names and roles of board and executive leaders.

What is the rationale for this step: Introduces students to the help resources available and fosters early help-seeking behaviors.

Walkthrough video (≤60 seconds) showing how to submit a Help Desk ticket.

Step title: Try It: Find the Right Contact
What is the rationale for this step: Gives students hands-on practice matching questions with the correct support channel.
Content Outline:
Interactive checklist or drag-and-drop: “Match the question to the right contact method.”
Examples like password reset vs. transcript request vs. teacher feedback.

What is the rationale for this step: Reinforces learning by encouraging students to consider which support method they’d use first.
Content Outline: Prompt: “Which support channel will you use first if you need help, and why?”

What is the rationale for this step: Students need a concise, sequential list of actions to begin smoothly (e.g., portal login, technology check, handbook download). This sets momentum for independent, self-paced learning.
Content Outline:
Bullet-list onboarding tasks with expected completion time.
Call-out: “Save this checklist—refer back any time.”

What is the rationale for this step: Students must know where to go for help with common technical issues. This encourages self-advocacy and smoother onboarding.
Content Outline:
Link to Help Desk video from Module 2 for ticket support.
Reminder that support is available during school hours via Help Desk.
Tip: Add Help Desk to your bookmarks for quick access.

What is the rationale for this step: Clarifies the culture of self-motivation and ownership that differs from brick-and-mortar schools, reducing future misunderstandings.
Content Outline:
Self-paced but disciplined: 20 hrs/week minimum (under 18).
Role of instructors vs. student responsibility.

Step title: A Day in the Life at EHS
What is the rationale for this step: Offers a relatable snapshot of successful online study habits to model expectations.
Content Outline:
Quick scenario: “A day in the life of a successful EHS learner.”
Reflection prompt: “List two strategies you’ll use to stay motivated.”

What is the rationale for this step: Many students arrive with prior coursework—clarifying policies early helps them plan a realistic path to graduation.

Sources accepted (regionally accredited U.S. schools, qualified homeschool, evaluated international transcripts).
Step-by-step: how to submit transcripts and timeline for review.
Tip box: links to Credit Transfer & Homeschool policy pages.

What is the rationale for this step: Explains how much credit can be transferred and what must be completed at EHS—important for planning timelines and compliance.
Content Outline:
Maximum 75% transfer; diploma residency requirement (5.5–6 EHS credits).
Link to residency policy in student handbook.

What is the rationale for this step: An interactive comparison table plus self-check quiz helps learners choose the load that matches their goals and obligations.

Written request and parent signature via Help Desk.

One‑time limit per grade level.

Criteria: reasonable progress and legitimate reason.
$200 fee for two‑month extension.

24/7/365 platform access.

Step title: What EHS Can and Cannot Provide

Content Outline:
Describe EHS’s discretionary-support policy.
Give examples of accommodations considered (e.g., extended time).
List services not offered (e.g., in-person paraprofessionals, curriculum modification).
Emphasize self-paced, asynchronous learning model and Least Restrictive Environment (LRE) consideration.

Step title: How to Request and Document Support
What is the rationale for this step: Gives families a practical roadmap for submitting documentation so expectations are clear from day one.

Outline disclosure process during enrollment.

Step title: Student Responsibilities in the Support Process
What is the rationale for this step: Clarifies accountability so students stay engaged and parents understand attendance and communication duties.

Define student responsibilities: initiative, proactive help-seeking, time management.

What is the rationale for this step: Clarifies accountability so students stay engaged and parents understand attendance and communication duties.

Define parent/guardian roles: supportive learning space, monitoring progress via Parent Portal, ensuring attendance compliance.

What is the rationale for this step: Establishes zero-tolerance stance and outlines progressive discipline so learners feel secure.

Summarize investigation process and retaliation policy.
List consequences: warnings, probation, removal, expulsion.

Content Outline:
Explain educational purpose of school tech systems.
Emphasize no expectation of privacy.

What is the rationale for this step: Translates legal CIPA requirements into everyday do’s and don’ts, reducing tech-related infractions.

What is the rationale for this step: Establishes foundational knowledge by defining dual enrollment, outlining eligibility (grades 10–12, full‑time status, minimum six EHS credits), and linking benefits to learner goals of early college credit and cost savings. Builds motivation before moving to practical details.
Content Outline:
Definition of dual enrollment & credit equivalence (3 college credits = 1.0 HS credit).
Eligibility criteria, age exceptions for advanced 9th‑graders.
Key benefits: accelerate graduation, lower tuition, smooth transition to college.
Quick infographic comparing traditional vs. dual‑enrollment timelines.

What is the rationale for this step: Short (≤ 90 s) video humanises the partnerships—“show” over “tell”—through campus clips and coach narration, increasing emotional engagement and credibility.
Content Outline:
Logo montage of partner colleges.

Call‑to‑action: download approved course list.

What is the rationale for this step: Guides students to practical tools (Peterson’s Career & Test Prep, Success Coach advising) so they can apply information immediately—aligned with adult‑learning need for relevance and action.

Checklist: documents to collect (transcripts, course syllabi) for credit transfer.

What is the rationale for this step: Encourages active learning—students apply module insights to draft a personalised action plan, supporting self‑paced, asynchronous environment and diverse learner goals.

Drag‑and‑drop task: map chosen dual‑enrollment courses to intended major.
Reflection prompts: barriers & solutions, support people, key dates.
Option to export PDF for coach feedback.

What is the rationale for this step: Consolidates learning with a concise checklist and links, ensuring clarity on immediate actions and maintaining momentum.

What is the rationale for this step: Consolidates learning with a concise checklist and links, ensuring clarity on immediate actions and maintaining momentum.
Content Outline: FAQ accordion on tuition, textbooks, failing a course.

What is the rationale for this step: Before checking hardware or software, students must confirm they possess core skills—web navigation, email, and office-suite use—required across all courses. Establishing this baseline aligns with the learning outcome and scaffolds later technical instructions.

Define “basic digital literacy” for EHS.
Skills checklist: navigating the internet; sending email with attachments; creating/editing docs in Google Docs, Microsoft Office, or OpenOffice.

What is the rationale for this step: Before checking hardware or software, students must confirm they possess core skills—web navigation, email, and office-suite use—required across all courses. Establishing this baseline aligns with the learning outcome and scaffolds later technical instructions.
Content Outline:
Link to quick video tutorials and printable tip sheet.
Reflection prompt: “Which skill feels least familiar? Note one action you’ll take this week to practice it.”

What is the rationale for this step: Students need concrete device and connectivity specs before beginning coursework; unmet requirements are the most common cause of support tickets. Presenting them early prevents delays.
Content Outline:
Minimum device standards (desktop/laptop preferred; Chromebooks acceptable with limits; tablets/phones not allowed for exams).
Internet expectations: stable broadband suggested for video-rich lessons; reminder that EHS is fully online.

Content Outline:
Required productivity tools (Google Docs/Sheets or Microsoft Office) and where to access free options.
Mobile-device limitations (view-only; no exams).
How to enable pop-ups for external resources.

What is the rationale for this step: Empowering students to solve common issues first builds self-efficacy and reduces wait times for help. An interactive checklist guides them through basic fixes before submitting a ticket.

What is the rationale for this step: Empowering students to solve common issues first builds self-efficacy and reduces wait times for help. An interactive checklist guides them through basic fixes before submitting a ticket.

What is the rationale for this step: Students first need a clear picture of the cost of their program before they can choose a payment option or enroll.

What is the rationale for this step: Learners must choose a payment schedule and know how refunds work to avoid financial surprises.

Credit-Transfer Guarantee and 10-day full-refund window (minus 3% fee).

What is the rationale for this step: Learners must choose a payment schedule and know how refunds work to avoid financial surprises.
